title: Lebanese army boosts its presence along border with Israel, dismantling Hezbollah posts
ai_summary: The Lebanese army has significantly increased its presence along the border with Israel, deploying nearly 10,000 troops and dismantling Hezbollah posts in the aftermath of the Israel-Hezbollah war that ended with a ceasefire in November 2024. The army has closed 11 smuggling routes along the Litani River and discovered numerous weapons and tunnels previously used by Hezbollah, while also facing ongoing Israeli airstrikes. Despite the Lebanese government's support for a U.S.-backed disarmament plan, Hezbollah has rejected the initiative, asserting that it will not disarm until Israel ceases its attacks and withdraws from occupied territories.

title: Sugar Girlz Earn Crucial Draw Against Cuba
ai_summary: The St. Kitts and Nevis Senior Women’s National Team secured a crucial 2-2 draw against Cuba in their second Concacaf W Qualifiers match, with forward Phoenetia Browne scoring the opening goal. Despite falling behind 2-1 in the second half, the Sugar Girlz equalized thanks to an own goal from Cuba, earning a valuable point after their previous loss to Aruba. The team, now with one point from two matches, aims for a strong finish in Group E to qualify for the 2026 Concacaf W Championship.

title: Gift vouchers approved for baby milk purchases
ai_summary: The UK government has approved a plan allowing parents to use gift vouchers and supermarket loyalty points to purchase infant formula, aiming to make baby milk more affordable amid rising costs. The initiative includes clearer nutritional guidance for formula products and encourages retailers to offer cheaper options, potentially saving families up to £500 annually. Health officials emphasize the need for transparency in the infant formula market, addressing concerns that parents have been pressured into buying more expensive brands.

title: Another country bans phones in class saying children ‘need to see each other’s faces’
ai_summary: Chile has enacted a ban on mobile phones and smart devices in elementary and middle school classrooms, set to take effect in 2026, in a bid to reduce distractions and enhance social interactions among students. This decision aligns Chile with other countries that have implemented similar restrictions, and it follows years of advocacy from parents and teachers concerned about the impact of smartphones on children's learning and mental health. Education Minister Nicolás Cataldo emphasized the need for students to reconnect face-to-face and improve their concentration for better educational outcomes.

title: One man’s trash...Lotto winner hits $1M prize on ticket turned down by another player
ai_summary: A 33-year-old man from Michigan won a $1 million lottery prize after purchasing a ticket that another player had declined. The anonymous winner bought the $10 Blazing Suits ticket and opted for a lump-sum payment of about $693,000, expressing his intention to save the money. Michigan Lottery officials highlighted that the lottery contributes significantly to the state's school funding, with over $1 billion allocated to the School Aid Fund in Fiscal Year 2025.
